basedOn.display: MRI Whole Body MSK W/WO Contrast Prot

valueString:
RESULT:  CLINICAL HISTORY: Schwannomatosis and neuropathic pain. History 
of resection of a mass at the back of his head and a left apical lung 
mass in 2001.


TECHNIQUE: Whole body MRI was performed before and after intravenous 
administration of 8.5 cc of gadavist. Three-dimensional fluid sensitive 
sequences, diffusion-weighted images, pre- and post fat-saturated 
T1-weighted images were obtained.


COMPARISON: Whole body MRI from 11/7/2013.


BRAIN:


No definite intracranial enhancing abnormalities are identified on this 
limited large field of view study. No midline shift. The dural venous 
sinuses appear patent.


Again identified is soft tissue fullness of the scalp without definite 
enhancement to the left side of the occipital region ( image 85, series 
7, axial reformatted images).


Small air-fluid level in the right maxillary sinus, new from the previous 
study.


Stable appearing mucous retention cyst or polyp in the bilateral 
maxillary sinuses. No enhancement.


HEAD AND NECK STRUCTURES:


Minimal increase in size of a left occipital scalp lesion which now 
measures 4.5 x 2.4 x 2.2 cm. It has increased in size from the previous 
examination when it measured 3.9 x 2.8 x 1.5 cm. Heterogenous contrast 
enhancement is again identified. No suspicious ADC values are detected, 
however, there is artifact in this region on ADC map.


Stable 1.8 x 1 cm T2 hyperintense structure at the anterior edge of the 
jaw muscles on the left side. Minimal heterogenous enhancement


Stable 4 mm T2 hyperintense nodule without definite enhancement in the 
parotid gland.


Stable subcutaneous enhancing nodule measuring 6 mm in the left posterior 
subcutaneous location in the neck.


Stable T2 hyperintense nonenhancing structure adjacent to the spinous 
process on the left side, in the lower cervical spine.


Stable 5 mm enhancing focus in the left nasopharynx.


Stable heterogeneously enhancing T2 hyperintense lesion posterior to the 
larynx towards the left side measuring 1.5 x 1 cm.


Stable T2 hyperintense the subcentimeter lesion in the left jaw.


There is several other tiny masses identified which appears stable from 
the previous examination.


CHEST:


Bilateral apical lung masses, both of which are heterogeneously T2 
hypointense and do not demonstrate contrast enhancement. The right apical 
mass measures 3.6 x 2.4 cm and the left apical mass measures 2.3 x 1.3 
cm. Stable.


Along the bilateral nerve roots of C8, nonenhancing T2 hyperintense 
stable masses are identified measuring approximately 1.3 x 1 cm on the 
left side.


Paraspinal masses adjacent to the neural foramina are also identified at 
the level of T3. These masses are again heterogenous T2 hyperintense 
without enhancement and appear similar in size from the previous 
examination.


T2 hyperintense structure measuring 1 cm in short axis at the subcarinal 
location with enhancement and suggestion of a target sign, may represent 
another peripheral nerve sheath tumor.


The lesions in the chest were evaluated on the ADC map, and no definite 
suspicious low ADC values and were identified. However, evaluation of ADC 
maps is limited due to artifact.


ABDOMEN AND PELVIS:


At the left subdiaphragmatic region, there is a stable T2 hyperintense 
nonenhancing structure measuring 1 cm.


The liver, spleen, pancreas, adrenals, kidneys and gallbladder appear 
within normal limits. No definite enhancing or T2 hyperintense lesion is 
identified to suggest a peripheral nerve sheath tumor.


Evaluation of the pelvis and lower abdomen is markedly limited due to 
motion artifact from the bowel.


BILATERAL LOWER EXTREMITIES:


Stable trace bilateral hip effusions.


Trace bilateral hydroceles, stable.


No enhancing or T2 hyperintense lesions to suggest a peripheral nerve 
sheath tumor.


Small bilateral knee effusions.
